title: 111_hr6069
content: The Act titled "Making Home Affordable Improvements Act" allocates funding for foreclosure mitigation counseling in connection with the Home Affordable Modification Program and Home Affordable Foreclosure Alternatives Program. The Act allocates funding from the Making Home Affordable initiative for foreclosure mitigation counseling activities related to the Home Affordable Modification Program. The National Foreclosure Mitigation Counseling Program will distribute the assistance to eligible grantees following program guidelines. Housing counseling agencies must be recipients of National Foreclosure Mitigation Counseling Program funding to receive assistance. Funding amounts for mortgage modifications under the Home Affordable Modification Program are $500 for trial modifications and $750 for permanent modifications. The Home Affordable Foreclosure Alternatives Program offers $300 for each mortgage with an alternative to foreclosure. The Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation can use up to 15% of allocated funds for administrative expenses. The National Foreclosure Mitigation Counseling Program directs funds to housing counseling agencies. The National Foreclosure Mitigation Counseling Program refers to the program of the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation for mortgage foreclosure mitigation activities. The Secretary of the Treasury will revise guidelines of the Making Home Affordable initiative and the Home Affordable Modification Program to implement this program. SEC. 3. Collection of program data and disclosure to Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Secretary of the Treasury will collect comprehensive data on mortgage servicers and lenders participating in the Home Affordable Modification Program, including the number of modification requests received. The Program collects data on mortgage servicers and lenders for modifications, including requests processed for borrowers with high debt-to-income ratios. It also tracks trial modifications entered into with borrowers. The Program collects data on mortgage modifications, including requests processed for borrowers with high debt-to-income ratios and tracks trial modifications entered into with borrowers. The data includes the number of requests for mortgage modifications under the Program, permanent modifications with borrowers, denials, and those with a back-end debt-to-income ratio of 55 percent or higher. The Program collects data on mortgage modifications, including denials for borrowers with back-end debt-to-income ratios of 55 percent or higher. The Secretary provides monthly reports to HUD, and the Treasury makes the data publicly available within 30 days. The Secretary of the Treasury will publicly release a report on mortgage modifications through a website and to Congress as required by subsection (b). The Act defines the "back-end debt-to-income ratio" as the ratio of monthly payments on all debts to gross monthly income before modification under the Home Affordable Modification Program. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury.
